Award.AwardTitle: Zero-Cycles over Arithmetic Fields and Reciprocity Laws
Award.AbstractNarration: A central question in almost every science is the classification of objects that feature similar characteristics. In algebraic geometry, mathematicians are interested in the classification of algebraic varieties, that is, sets of solutions to polynomial equations. This classification is carried out by determining and computing certain invariants of the variety. Such invariants can be numerical, or more often, sets that have a specific algebraic or geometric structure. The more geometric approach focuses on algebraic varieties over the complex numbers, which themselves have a rich geometry. In number theory, on the other hand, mathematicians are interested in finding integer or rational solutions to polynomial equations; a famous example in this area is Fermat's last theorem. The set of rational numbers is very scarce within the set of complex numbers, which is what makes such solutions so hard to detect. This project aims to study a geometric invariant, called the Chow group of zero-cycles, that relates both to the classification problem and to the arithmetic of rational solutions. The main goal of the project is to investigate conjectures that deal with the structure of this group when we work over the rational numbers or over the arithmetic analog of the real numbers, namely the p-adic numbers. <br/><br/>The methods in this project will involve techniques from arithmetic and algebraic geometry as well as K-theory. The project focuses on the study of abelian varieties, a class of varieties that has some extra structure. The project involves "local questions" for varieties over the p-adic numbers, where the use of p-adic Hodge theory will be the key. Among the main goals of the local program is to establish a conjecture of Colliot-Thélène. Second, the project involves also "global questions" for varieties over the rational numbers. The goal of the global program will be to prove a conjecture of Beilinson. Lastly, the project will investigate a "local-to-global" program related to obstruction questions. The goal is to prove a conjecture of Kato and Saito, which could potentially lead to the construction of a new type of Euler system.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the period of this award (June 2020-September 2023) the following 7 research products were achieved.

1) Zero-cycles on a product of elliptic curves over a p-adic field. (Joint with I. Leal). IMRN 2022 (2021), no 14, p. 10586 -10625. 

2) Divisibility Results for zero-cycles. (Joint with T. Hiranouchi). European Journal of Math 7, p. 1458 - 1501 (2021). 

3) Weak Approximation for zero-cycles. (With an Appendix by A. Koutsianas). Appeared online in Math. Annalen. doi 10.1007/s00208-022-02553-y. 

4) Torsion phenomena for zero-cycles on a product of curves over a number field. (Joint with J. Love). Accepted for Publication in Research in Number Theory. (2022)

5) Abelian geometric fundamental groups for curves over a p-adic field. (Joint with T. Hiranouchi). Accepted for Publication in Journal de Theorie des Nombres de Bordeaux. (2022)

 6) Filtrations of the Chow group of zero-cycles on abelian varieties and behavior under isogenies. Preprint. Submitted for Publication. (2022) 

7) Hyperelliptic curves mapping to abelian varieties and applications to Beilinson's conjecture for zero-cycles. (Joint with J. Love). Upcoming preprint. (2023). 

 

The PI was involved in the following broader impacts. 

1) Organizer (together with Andrei Rapinchuk, Igor Rapinchuk and Ken Ono) of the weekly conference "Arithmetic Geometry and Algebraic Groups" which took place in May 24-28, 2023 at the University of Virginia. The conference, which included 17 main talks and 10 short communications by junior participants, was met with great success. The PI used a significant amount of this award (~$15,000) to fund the accommodation of about half the participants. 

2) The PI is a cofounder and member of the executive committee of the network "Greek Women in Mathematics", founded in June 2021. During a period of 2 years the network organized the follow activities: a) 2 virtual celebrations ("22 & '23) for the "Greek May 12", in memory of Maryam Mirzakhani's birthday, b) 3 podcast interviews (one co-hosted by the PI), c) a 2 day workshop held at the National Technical University of Athens in July 11-12, 2022. The workshop featured 14 short talks and a round table discussion. 

3) The PI has been supervising 2 phd students, Kian Aik Cheong and Michael Wills. Moreover, during the academic year 2021-2022 she supervised the Distinguished Major Thesis of Spencer Martin. 

4) At the University of Virginia: The PI has been co-organizing the weekly Math Club and has been energetically involved with the AWM student chapter. In the 2022-2023 academic year she co-organized the UVA Directed Reading Program. Lastly, the PI has been teaching mini-courses for the UVA REU program organized by Ken Ono since Summer 2021. 

5) The PI co-organized with Charlotte Ure an AMS special session at the 2021 JMM titled "Galois cohomology in Arithmetic Geometry". Moreover, together with Ken Ono she co-organized a special session for the AMS special section scheduled to take place at UVA but cancelled twice due to Covid-19.
